q: Is this Specification provided for future development work within oneM2M only?
Does the Partners accept liability for any use of this Specification?
Who owns the copyright of this document?
a: oneM2M Partners Type 1 (ARIB, ATIS, CCSA, ETSI, TIA, TSDSI, TTA, TTC)

q: Is there any representation or warranty made that the information is technically accurate or sufficient?
Does oneM2M make any representation or warranty of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose?
Is there any liability beyond the amount received in payment by the partner for this document?
a: Yes, no more than the amount received

q: What is the HTTP method for creating a resource?
What is the HTTP method for retrieving a resource?
What is the HTTP method for updating a resource?
What is the HTTP method for deleting a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for a successful creation of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for a successful retrieval of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for a successful update of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for a successful deletion of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for an unsuccessful creation of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for an unsuccessful retrieval of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for an unsuccessful update of a resource?
What is the HTTP Status code for an unsuccessful deletion of a resource?
What is the X-M2M-Origin header field used for?
a: Identifies the originator of the request

q: What is the X-M2M-RI header field used for?
What is the Content-Type header field used for?
a: Specifies the media type of the request body

q: What is the Host header field used for?
a: Identifies the server hosting the requested resource

q: What are the oneM2M codes for CTS, CTO, RVI, VSI, AS, and ASRI?
a: CTS17, CTO18, RVI18, VSI18, AS18, ASRI18

q: What is the section about Message-body?
What is the section about Message Routing?
What is the section about Security Consideration?
How to authenticate on HTTP Request Message?
What is the Transport Layer Security section about?
What is the purpose of Annex A (informative): Example Procedures?
What is the purpose of Annex B (informative): WebSocket?
What is bound to HTTP method in oneM2M compliant systems?
What are the oneM2M response status codes mapped to?
How are oneM2M RESTful resources bound in this document?
What are the types of references in this document?
What applies to specific references?
What applies to non-specific references?
a: The latest version of the reference document (including any amendments) applies

q: Which IETF RFC is referenced for HTTP/1.1: Message Syntax and Routing?
What is the publication date of RFC 7230?
Which oneM2M Technical Specification (TS) is referenced for Security Solutions?
Which IETF RFC is referenced for HTTP/1.1: Authentication?
What is the publication date of RFC 6750?
Which oneM2M Technical Specification (TS) is referenced for Common Terminology?
What are the IETF RFCs referenced in this text?
a: IETF RFC 7232, IETF RFC 3986, and IETF RFC 7231

q: What is the title of IETF RFC 7232?
What is the publication date of IETF RFC 7232?
What is the title of IETF RFC 3986?
What is the publication date of IETF RFC 3986?
What is the title of IETF RFC 7231?
What is the publication date of IETF RFC 7231?
What type of references are there in this document?
How is the cited version applied for specific references?
How is the latest version of a reference document applied for non-specific references?
a: The latest version, including any amendments, applies.

q: What is the URL to access oneM2M Drafting Rules?
What is the abbreviation for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol?
What is the abbreviation for Transport Layer Security?
What is the abbreviation for Uniform Resource Identifier?
How to interpret keywords in this document?
a: As described in the oneM2M Drafting Rules [i.1] (Shall, Shall not, May, Need not, Should, Should not)

q: What does HTTP binding specify in oneM2M?
a: the equivalence between oneM2M request and response primitives and HTTP request and response messages, respectively.

q: What is the purpose of this clause?
a: to provide a brief overview on the mapping relationship between oneM2M and HTTP message parameters.

q: How are oneM2M request/response primitives mapped to HTTP request/response messages?
a: This clause describes how oneM2M request/response primitives can be mapped to HTTP request/response messages and vice versa.

q: What takes the role of an HTTP client in the oneM2M system configuration?
What takes the role of a HTTP Proxy Server in the oneM2M system configuration?
What takes the roles of a HTTP server for this particular request message in the oneM2M system configuration?
How are CSEs related to HTTP protocol binding?
a: CSEs generally provide capability of both HTTP Server and HTTP Client.

q: What is the mapping between oneM2M request primitives and HTTP requests?
a: Each individual request primitive will be mapped to single HTTP request message

q: What is the mapping between oneM2M response primitives and HTTP responses?
a: Each individual response primitive will be mapped to a single HTTP response message

q: Can AE's provide HTTP Server capability optionally?
a: Yes, in order to serve Notification request messages

q: What are the components of an HTTP request message?
What are the components of an HTTP response message?
Are HTTP header names case-sensitive?
How should a Receiver handle HTTP header names?
a: Accept headers that are either lower or upper or any mixture thereof

q: How is the HTTP method of a request message mapped in oneM2M?
a: mapped to the Operation parameter, and vice-versa.

q: What is derived from the To parameter of the request primitive at the message originator side?
What carries other specific primitive parameters in the query string?
Where is the HTTP Version specified in the text?
How is the Status-Code of HTTP response messages derived from the oneM2M system?
a: from the Response Status Code parameter of the response primitive

q: Is the Reason-Phrase applicable to oneM2M systems?
How many use cases are there for mapping between oneM2M primitives and HTTP messages?
What is the first use case for mapping between oneM2M primitives and HTTP messages?
a: Mapping of request primitive to HTTP request message at the request originator (HTTP client)

q: Where do all four use cases also appear?
What is specified in the following clauses?
a: The mapping between each oneM2M primitive parameter and a corresponding HTTP message field to compose a HTTP request/response message

q: How is the HTTP 'Method' derived from the Operation request primitive parameter?
a: from the Operation request primitive parameter of the request primitive.

q: What is the HTTP method mapped to at the Receiver for an HTTP POST request?
a: either a Create or Notify Operation parameter

q: How can discrimination between Create and Notify operations be accomplished in an HTTP POST request?
a: by inspection of the content-type header

q: Is the Resource Type parameter present in the content-type header for a Create or Notify request?
a: present only when the HTTP POST request represents a Create request

q: How is the path component of the origin-form HTTP Request-Target interpreted?
a: The mapping of the resource identifier part of the To request primitive parameter.

q: What form of Request-Target is employed when sending an HTTP message directly to the next hop CSE?
How many different forms can the resource identifier part of the To parameter be represented in?
What are the three formats that may include either a structured Resource ID or an unstructured Resource ID?
How is the path component of the HTTP request message constructed for CSE-relative Resource ID representation?
a: concatenation of the literal “/” and the To request primitive parameter.

q: What character is used to replace the first “/” character in the To request primitive parameter for Absolute Resource ID representation?
How is the path component of the HTTP request message constructed for SP-relative Resource ID representation?
a: concatenation of the literal “/~” and the To request primitive parameter.

q: What is the valid mapping between the To request primitive parameter and the path component of the origin-form HTTP request target?
a: /myCSEID and /CSE178 represent applicable CSI-IDs, CSEBase represents the resource name of a <CSEBase> resource, CSEBase/ae12/cont27/contInst696 represents a structured CSE-relative resource ID, and cin00856 an unstructured CSE-relative resource ID.

q: How to derive a replica of the original To request primitive parameter from the path component of request-line at the HTTP server side?
a: The reverse operations shall be applied.

q: What form of Request-Target is employed when sending an HTTP message to a HTTP proxy instead directly to the next hop CSE?
How is the absolute-form of Request-Target derived?
a: Prefixing the origin-form with the schema and the host address of the next hop CSE.

q: What is the format of the request-line in an HTTP message?
a: http://{host address of next hop CSE}{origin-form path-component}

q: What is included in the query component (e.g. query-string) of a request?
a: The optional primitive parameters listed in table 6.2.2.2-1 compliant with IETF RFC 7230 [1]

q: How are applicable request primitive parameters and elements of Filter Criteria parameter represented in the query-string?
a: As a pair of field-name and value

q: What character is used as a separator between two pairs in the query-string?
What does multiplicity '0..1' mean in the query-string?
a: A parameter is optional and can occur at most once.

q: How are parameters with multiplicity '0..n' represented in the query-string?
What is the representation of a list type for resourceType element of Filter Criteria parameter?
How are multiple occurrences of contentType and labels elements represented in the query-string?
a: The same representation as resourceType element

q: What is the structure of 'attribute' element of Filter Criteria request primitive parameter?
How are attribute names represented in the query-string?
a: in the form of short names as defined in clause 8.2.3 of TS-0004 [3] and separated by '&'.

q: What is the XML representation of a single attribute element?
How are multiple attribute elements represented in the query-string?
How are 'childAttribute' and 'parentAttribute' elements handled in Filter Criteria request primitive?
a: In a similar way to the 'attribute' element.

q: What prefix is added to each attribute name for 'childAttribute'?
What prefix is added to each attribute name for 'parentAttribute'?
How are sequences of attribute elements mapped in the query string for 'childAttribute'?
a: by adding a prefix to each attribute name respectively: c.attname1=attvalue1&c.attname2=attvalue2

q: How are sequences of attribute elements mapped in the query string for 'parentAttribute'?
a: by adding a prefix to each attribute name respectively: p.attname1=attvalue1&p.attname2=attvalue2

q: What is an example of valid Request-Target representation for 'nonBlockingRequestSynch'?
What is the Response Type for 'nonBlockingRequestSynch'?
What is the Result Persistence for 'nonBlockingRequestSynch'?
What is an example of valid Request-Target representation for Discovery?
What are the primitive parameters for Request-Target in Example 2)?
What is the filter criteria for resourceType in Example 2)?
What is the attribute name for creator in Example 2)?
What is the attribute value for creator in Example 2)?
What is the filter usage for discovery in Example 2)?
What is the Request-Target for Example 2)?
What are the primitive parameters for Semantic Discovery in Example 3)?
How is semanticsFilter encoded in SPARQL?
What are the primitive parameters in this example?
What is the filter criteria for semantics?
What is the SELECT statement in this query?
What is the Request-Target for this request?
What short names can be used in the query-string?
a: Any of the short names listed in table 6.2.2.2-1, with the exception of ‘atr’

q: What is an alternative to using 'atr' in the query-string?
a: Resource attribute short names as listed in tables 8.2.3-1 to 8.2.3-5 in oneM2M TS-0004 [3]

q: What is omitted from the resource attribute short names list?
a: Those that shall be omitted (see clause 7.3.3.17.9 in oneM2M TS-0004 [3])

q: How are resource attributes included in the fragment component of request-target?
a: It shall follow any required query-string separated by ‘#’ character.

q: What is used to separate multiple attribute names in the fragment component?
How are multiple resource attributes included in a partial retrieve request primitive?
a: Included in form of an attributeList object (as specified in Table 6.3.3-1 of TS-0004 [3]) in the Content parameter.

q: How are single resource attributes included in a partial retrieve request primitive?
a: The To parameter may include the name of a single attribute separated by a ‘#’ character from the resource ID.

q: How are query components attached to the request-target in oneM2M?
a: via the 'atrl' parameter in the Content primitive parameter or the To parameter separated by '#' character.

q: What is omitted from the path component of the request line?
How are query components attached to the request-target in oneM2M when multiple attributes are indicated in the Content primitive parameter?
What is omitted from the path component of the request line when a single attribute is indicated in the To parameter separated by '#' character?
How are query components attached to the request-target in oneM2M when a single attribute is indicated in the To parameter separated by '#' character?
What is the value of the <op> element in this example?
What is the value of the <to> element in this example?
What is the value of the <fr> element in this example?
What is the value of the <rqi> element in this example?
What is the value of the <ty> element in this example?
How are single attribute names in the query component mapped back into the HTTP request message?
a: Either by following a ‘#’ character or included into the Content parameter using the attributeList format with just a single list element included.

q: What is the correct way to include multiple attributes from the query component into the Content parameter?
What is the HTTP version field in HTTP request messages set to?
What is the HTTP version field in HTTP response messages set to?
How are Response Status Code parameter values mapped to HTTP status codes?
a: one or more Response Status Code value may be mapped to the same HTTP Status-Code.

q: What is carried in the X-M2M-RSC header?
a: The original Response Status Code parameter value

q: Where can one find the mapping of Response Status Code parameter value of oneM2M request primitive to Status-Code of HTTP request messages?
Is the Reason-Phrase omitted in HTTP response messages?
Which protocol binding does this clause support?
How do unrecognized HTTP headers affect the HTTP client and server?
Is the Host header present in each HTTP request message?
What does the Host header indicate in multi-hop communication scenarios?
a: The FQDN or IP address of the Receiver CSE of the next hop

q: Is the Request-Target changed when a request is forwarded to the next hop CSE?
What happens to the Host header when no HTTP proxy is used?
a: It is set as one of the pointOfAccess attribute values of the Receiver

q: How is the origin-form of target URI used in multi-hop communication scenarios without an HTTP proxy?
What happens to the Host header when an HTTP request message is sent to a HTTP proxy rather than to the next hop CSE?
a: It is set to the FQDN or IP address of the proxy

q: How is the absolute-form of target URI used in scenarios with an HTTP proxy?
What are the acceptable media types for the response?
a: application/xml, application/json, application/cbor, or oneM2M defined media types in clause 6.7 of oneM2M TS-0004 [3]

q: Are all oneM2M defined media types applicable for the response?
What are the allowed values for the Content-Type header in an HTTP request or response containing a message-body?
a: application/xml, application/json, or oneM2M defined media types (clause 6.7 of oneM2M TS-0004)

q: How should the Content-Type of the HTTP response be chosen by the Hosting CSE?
a: Considering the Accept header given in the HTTP request

q: What is appended to the Content-type of the corresponding HTTP request message for Create request primitives?
a: The value of the Resource Type primitive parameter in the form ty=value, separated by a semicolon character

q: What are some examples of valid Content-Type headers for Create request primitives?
a: application/vnd.onem2m-res+xml; ty=3, application/vnd.onem2m-res+json; ty=3, application/vnd.onem2m-res+cbor; ty=3

q: What is set to the Content-Location header of the HTTP response to a Create request?
a: the URI of the created resource, if this URI is present in the Content parameter of the Create response primitive.

q: Where can one find more information about setting the Content-Location header for a Create request?
a: See clause 7.3.3.12 “Create a success response” in oneM2M TS-0004 [3]

q: What header field indicates the length of the message-body in octets (8-bit bytes)?
What is included into HTTP request or response messages when a message-body is present?
What should be included in a response primitive sent in reply to a resource retrieval request primitive?
a: an Etag header and the resource representation in the HTTP message body.

q: What does Etag facilitate?
What are the if-match and if-none-match HTTP headers used for?
Which RFC should a CSE support if it supports the Etag header?
What header field is mapped to the From parameter of request and response primitives?
Is X-M2M-Origin applicable for mapping?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-RI header?
a: Request Identifier parameter of request and response primitives and vice versa.

q: What is the purpose of the X-M2M-RI header?
a: The X-M2M-RI header shall be mapped to the Request Identifier parameter of request and response primitives and vice versa.

q: What is mapped to the X-M2M-GID header?
a: Group Request Identifier parameter of request primitives and vice versa, if applicable.

q: How is the X-M2M-RTU header mapped?
a: to the notificationURI element of the Response Type parameter of request primitives and vice versa, if applicable.

q: What character is used to combine multiple values in an element?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-OT header?
a: Originating Timestamp parameter of request and response primitives, and vice versa, if applicable.

q: What are the primitives that the Originating Timestamp parameter is mapped to?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-RST header?
a: Result Expiration Timestamp parameter of request and response primitives, and vice versa, if applicable.

q: Is the mapping bidirectional?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-RET header?
a: Request Expiration Timestamp parameter of request primitives and vice versa, if applicable.

q: What is mapped to the X-M2M-OET header?
a: Operation Execution Time parameter of request primitives and vice versa, if applicable.

q: Is the X-M2M-OET header applicable for both request primitives and vice versa?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-EC header?
a: Event Category parameter of request and response primitives, and vice versa, if applicable.

q: What is mapped to the Response Status Code parameter of response primitives?
a: The X-M2M-RSC header in a HTTP response message.

q: What are the oneM2M codes 4000 and 4102 mapped to in the HTTP Status Code?
How should the X-M2M-ATI header be mapped in a HTTP response message?
a: to the Assigned Token Identifiers parameter of response primitives and vice versa.

q: What is the format of the X-M2M-ATI header?
a: a sequence of lti-value:tkid-value pairs separated by a colon “:’ and multiple pairs appended with ‘+’ character.

q: How are multiple pairs in the X-M2M-ATI header separated?
What is an example of a valid X-M2M-ATI header?
How are the Assigned Token Identifiers parameter and the X-M2M-ATI header related in XML representation?
a: the XML representation of the Assigned Token Identifiers parameter is given as <ati>…</ati>

q: What is the data type of the Assigned Token Identifiers parameter?
How is the Tokens primitive parameter represented?
a: A space separated list of JSON Web Signature (JWS) and JSON Web Encryption (JWE) strings in Compact Serialization format of datatype m2m:dynAuthJWT.

q: What is the format of each individual token in the Tokens primitive parameter when mapped into the Authorization header?
How are multiple tokens separated in the Authorization header?
What is an example of an Authorization header in oneM2M?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-CTS header?
a: Content Status parameter of response primitives and vice versa, if applicable.

q: What is mapped to the Content Offset parameter of response primitives?
What is vice versa of X-M2M-CTO header mapping?
a: Content Offset parameter of response primitives

q: What is mapped to the X-M2M-RVI header?
a: Release Version Indicator parameter of request and response primitives, and vice versa.

q: Is the mapping bidirectional?
What is mapped to the X-M2M-VSI header?
a: Vendor Information parameter of request and response primitives, and vice versa.

q: How is the Authorization Signatures parameter mapped to the X-M2M-AS header?
a: It shall be mapped to the X-M2M-AS header.

q: What is the data type of the individual signature in the Authorization Signatures primitive parameter?
How are individual signatures separated when mapped into the X-M2M-AS header?
What is an example of a list of two elements in the Authorization Signatures parameter?
What does the X-M2M-AS header look like for a list of two elements in the Authorization Signatures parameter?
Are whitespace characters significant in the X-M2M-AS header?
Should line breaks be included into the X-M2M-AS header?
What is mapped to the Authorization Signature Request Information parameter of response primitives and vice versa in an HTTP response message?
Where is the message-body mapped in request and response primitives?
Which primitives have exceptions for mapping Content parameter?
What attributes are mapped to the fragment component of request-target in Partial Retrieve request primitive?
a: Attributes contained in the Content parameter

q: How is a Token Request Information parameter included in a response primitive mapped?
a: Into the message-body as a XML or JSON serialized object

q: What headers are set for data representation?
What should error response messages include in the Message-Body?
a: Token Request Information parameter only, no debugging information.

Which HTTP header should be used to send credentials to be checked by the Registrar CSE?
Which HTTP header should be used to send credentials to be checked by the Hosting CSE?
What authentication scheme should be used when sending an Access Token compatible with OAuth 2.0 framework to the Hosting CSE?
How are oneM2M primitive parameters protected in HTTP messages?
Where can the details of TLS protection be found?
What is the name of the <CSEBase> resource of the registrar CSE?
What is the name of the created <container> resource chosen by the registrar CSE?
Can WebSocket be used for transporting notifications to an AE/CSE?
What is the use case of using WebSocket for an AE/CSE that is not server-capable or cannot be reachable?
How does an AE establish a connection to a CSE for receiving notifications?
